title: Introducing the New Product Enhancement Request System
description: This training covers the launch of Gladly's new centralized Product Enhancement Request (PER) system in Salesforce, which enables sales, CS, and product teams to effectively capture, track, and prioritize customer feedback to inform the product roadmap.
keyTakeaways: A centralized system in Salesforce to capture, track, and prioritize customer enhancement requests, linking them directly to opportunities for revenue impact quantification.
Full visibility into request statuses and histories per customer for Sales, CS, and SE teams.
Richer context and faster access to requests for Product teams, including details on how individual customers intend to use features.
Data-driven roadmap decisions based on direct links between customer feedback and revenue impact.
Replaces fragmented feedback process where feedback got lost, trends were hard to track, and 'loudest' requests won.

articleSections.heading: Associated Opportunity
articleSections.content: Select the opportunity this request is linked to for revenue impact tracking.

articleSections.heading: Main Contact
articleSections.content: Identify the primary customer contact requesting the enhancement.

articleSections.heading: Impact Level
articleSections.content: Define the impact: Deal Breaker, Challenge, or Nice to Have.

articleSections.heading: Primary Competitor
articleSections.content: Note if this request is influenced by competitive pressure.

articleSections.heading: Request Description
articleSections.content: Provide full context: customer's goal, use case, and any current workarounds.

actionItems: **Be specific about use cases:** Don't just say "customer wants X"—explain how they plan to use it and what problem it solves.
**Connect to revenue:** Always link to an opportunity. Requests without revenue context are harder to prioritize.
**Check for duplicates:** Search existing PERs before creating new ones. Add your customer's voice to existing requests when applicable.
**Update status regularly:** If circumstances change (deal closes, customer churns, priority shifts), update the PER to keep data accurate.
Don't submit vague requests without context or use case details.
Don't create duplicate PERs instead of adding to existing ones.
Don't use PERs for bugs or minor UI feedback that belong in other channels.
Don't forget to follow up or update PERs when deal status changes.

contentBlocks.title: Overview
contentBlocks.content:
What It Is — A centralized system in Salesforce to capture, track, and prioritize customer enhancement requests, linking them directly to opportunities for revenue impact quantification.
Who It's For — Sales, CS, and SE teams submitting customer feedback; Product teams reviewing and prioritizing requests; Leadership making data-driven roadmap decisions.
Key Outcome — Full visibility into request status, history, and product commitment for each customer—enabling data-driven decisions that connect customer feedback to revenue impact.
Why It Matters — Replaces fragmented feedback process. Leadership can now make roadmap decisions based on direct links between customer feedback and revenue potential.

contentBlocks.title: Challenges with the Previous Process
contentBlocks.content:
Prior to the new system, the product enhancement request process was fragmented, leading to several major challenges:
✕ **Feedback got lost:** Requests submitted through various channels without central tracking made it difficult to maintain visibility.
✕ **Hard to track trends:** Without aggregation, product teams struggled to identify patterns and prioritize effectively.
✕ **No revenue connection:** Requests weren't tied to opportunities, making it impossible to quantify impact.
✕ **"Loudest" requests won:** Without data, only the most vocal requests got attention—not necessarily the highest-impact ones.

contentBlocks.title: Introducing the New PER System
contentBlocks.content: Gladly has built a new centralized Product Enhancement Request (PER) system within Salesforce to capture, track, and help prioritize customer enhancement requests. By linking requests directly to opportunities, the system can quantify them with dollar amounts and customer segments, empowering product teams to focus resources on the highest impact efforts.

contentBlocks.title: PER Submission Guidelines
contentBlocks.content:
What Should Be a PER:
✓ Feature requests that would impact customer decisions or satisfaction
✓ Enhancements that address competitive gaps
✓ Requests tied to specific opportunities with revenue impact

What Should NOT Be a PER:
✕ Minor UI/UX improvements—use standard bug/feedback channels
✕ Basic bug reports—use typical support channels
contentBlocks.callout: **Collaboration Tip:** All teams are empowered to submit PERs, but AEs and SEs are encouraged to work closely together to avoid duplicates. Product and CS teams will review requests monthly and refine as needed.

faqs.question: Where can I see all PERs for my accounts?
faqs.answer: A temporary Salesforce report showing all PERs will be shared shortly. A comprehensive Tableau dashboard is planned for this quarter, and we're exploring ways to link the full PER list directly within Salesforce for easy access.

faqs.question: How often are PERs reviewed?
faqs.answer: Product and CS teams review requests monthly. High-priority requests (Deal Breakers) may be escalated for faster review.

faqs.question: Can I submit a PER for a prospect?
faqs.answer: Yes, as long as there's an associated opportunity. The system is designed to capture feedback from both customers and prospects.

faqs.question: What happens after I submit a PER?
faqs.answer: The request enters the review queue. You'll have visibility into status changes, and product teams may reach out for additional context if needed.

contentBlocks.title: Action Items
contentBlocks.content:
1. **Submit a PER** — Submit a PER for any customer enhancement requests, partnering with AEs and SEs to avoid duplicates.
2. **Review the report** — Review the temporary Salesforce report of all PERs to stay informed on what has been requested.
